#Text=Get a Second Opinion Before Major Surgery

#Text=If your primary care physician ( PCP ) has referred you to a specialist , and that doctor has recommended a major surgical procedure , it would be wise to get a " second opinion " before proceeding .

column1: #Text=Doing so means you seek additional experience and perspective at an important moment in your life .
#Text=It typically involves a reinforced commitment to the original diagnosis and treatment plan suggested by your doctor .
#Text=It can give you confidence in the proposed surgery .
#Text=It can fine-tune the suggested course of action .
#Text=It could even postpone or radically change the plan .
#Text=Patients have a right to a second ( and third ) opinion and are well advised to seek them .
#Text=You want all the help you can get at a critical time .
#Text=Major surgery is disruptive and expensive .
#Text=You want to be sure it 's necessary before you agree to it .
#Text=There are sometimes acceptable alternatives to major surgery .
#Text=Be an educated consumer when it comes to your health and well being , just as you would in any other area of life .
#Text=Different physicians take different approaches to health care , some more aggressive than others .
#Text=A second opinion may suggest a better option for you than the first one suggested .
#Text=Here 's how to go about this .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Ask around .
#Text=Surgery is normally considered the last line of treatment .
#Text=Doctors usually try to avoid it when possible , because it 's invasive , complicated and even dangerous .
#Text=Nonetheless , it may be urgently required , and it may be considered the patient 's best option .
#Text=Seek confirmation from another doctor ( or doctors ) that the proposed surgery is indeed your best option .
#Text=Find such doctors by searching physician-locator sites online or by asking for references from area clinics , hospitals and HMOs .
#Text=Do not fear a second opinion .
#Text=Do n't worry about offending your PCP .
#Text=A good doctor will encourage you to seek a second opinion .
#Text=S/he may well seek a second opinion , too .
#Text=In this age of high medical costs , insurance companies often encourage doctors to avoid expensive surgeries , so your doctor will probably want a confirming opinion before ordering surgery .
#Text=Some patients may worry that a second opinion may confuse them and prevent from taking the right decision .
#Text=In fact , quite the opposite is true .
#Text=The better informed you are , the better decision you can make .
#Text=Do your own research .
#Text=Inform yourself about your situation by conducting research online or in medical texts .
#Text=If you do this before conferring with a specialist , it will help you understand what the doctor tells you as you work toward a decision .

#Text=According to the American Journal of Medicine , a recent assessment of more than 6,000 patients showed that second opinions do have a positive impact on diagnoses , treatment plans and surgical outcomes .

#Text=Specifically , within the assessed patients second opinions resulted in changed diagnoses 15 % of the time , changed treatment plans 37 % of the time , and both changed diagnoses and changed treatment 10 % of the time .
#Text=Get the correct diagnosis .
#Text=A second opinion will confirm your original diagnosis and treatment plan , or it will modify them .
#Text=In either case it may save you time , money , and unnecessary treatment .
#Text=Before going for a second opinion , research the physician .
#Text=Get the second opinion from a specialist known to be skilled and experienced in treating patients with your condition .
#Text=Not all physicians are absolutely up-to-date on new studies , treatments , procedures and diagnoses .
#Text=So a second opinion from a specialist is especially valuable .
#Text=Get a second opinion before elective surgery .
#Text=When you have time to consider other treatment options , finding other opinions is especially appropriate .
#Text=In the case of emergency surgery , you may not have that luxury .
#Text=Remember that seeking a second opinion does not mean you 're choosing alternate treatment ; it just means you 're being careful .
#Text=A second opinion will help you in the following situations :
#Text=You want to make sure that surgery is the only appropriate option left for you .
#Text=You are not satisfied with the answers given by the first doctor .
#Text=You are not able to make a decision .
#Text=You want to explore other treatment options .
#Text=You want help from a specialist in deciding .
#Text=You want more information about your condition .
#Text=You want to confirm that the first diagnosis and treatment plan is right .
#Text=You want to know more about possible risks and complications .
#Text=Consider seeking a third opinion .
#Text=If the second opinion confirms the first , you will probably be satisfied that you 're on the right course .
#Text=If you 're still not satisfied , however , or if the second opinion contradicts the first , you should look for a third opinion .
#Text=Also take into consideration your own feelings and opinions , your lifestyle , and the fact that you 're the one who has to live with the final decision .
#Text=Just do n't let simple fear overrule the experience the doctors bring to bear on your situation .
#Text=They 're staking their reputations on the decisions they make .
